verses.text: Incline your ear, O LORD, and answer me, for I am poor and needy.
verses.comment: David opens in humility, confessing his neediness before God. The plea to 'incline your ear' is a metaphor, not a claim the Lord has a physical ear. Note the posture of humility—essential in all true prayer and echoed through Christian liturgy.

verses.text: Guard my life, for I am devoted to you. You are my God; save your servant who trusts in you.
verses.comment: The phrase 'devoted to you' (Heb. chasid) can be read as 'holy.' Early Christian writers see such devotion as a mark of sanctification—a subtle pointer to the transforming grace outlined in Catholic sacramental theology.

verses.text: Be merciful to me, O Lord, for I call upon you all day long.
verses.comment: Continual prayer points to the importance of perseverance. The appeal to divine mercy foreshadows the New Testament teaching on God’s mercy in Christ—see Luke 18:1–8.

verses.text: Make the soul of your servant glad, for to you, O Lord, I lift up my soul.
verses.comment: 'Lifting up the soul' anticipates Christian themes: in the Mass, the priest says, 'Lift up your hearts.' Such spiritual orientation subtly aligns with Catholic liturgical practice.

verses.text: For you, O Lord, are good and ready to forgive, abounding in mercy to all who call upon you.
verses.comment: God's readiness to forgive becomes a key element of Christ's ministry. Catholic theology especially emphasizes the sacrament of reconciliation as the means for this mercy to be encountered personally.

verses.text: Give ear, O LORD, to my prayer; listen to the voice of my supplication.
verses.comment: A universal invitation to prayer, reflected later in the teaching of Jesus on asking and receiving (Matthew 7:7).

verses.text: In the day of my trouble, I call upon you, for you will answer me.
verses.comment: David expresses assured faith that God responds to prayer. This confidence is echoed in Christ’s own prayers and promises to his followers.

verses.text: There is no one like you among the gods, O Lord, nor are there any works like yours.
verses.comment: Affirms God's uniqueness, pointing to monotheism. Christologically, this finds its fullness in Jesus, who is God made man (John 1:1–18).

verses.text: All nations whom you have made shall come and bow down before you, O Lord, and shall glorify your name.
verses.comment: A prophecy of universal worship. The Catholic Church sees its universality prefigured here, as all peoples are called to worship God—fulfilled in the Great Commission (Matt. 28:19–20).

verses.text: For you are great and do wondrous deeds; you alone are God.
verses.comment: The singular divinity of God is confirmed, echoing the Shema (Deut. 6:4). The wonders prefigure Christ’s miracles, his wondrous deeds.

verses.text: Teach me your way, O LORD, that I may walk in your truth; give me an undivided heart to fear your name.
verses.comment: The desire for instruction and unity of heart is reminiscent of discipleship and sanctification, vital to Christian growth. Catholics hold this intention central in prayers for guidance and steadfast faith.

verses.text: I will give thanks to you, O Lord my God, with all my heart, and I will glorify your name forever.
verses.comment: Praise of God with one's whole heart points to personal devotion, the foundation of all worship and Eucharistic thanksgiving (Eucharistia means 'thanksgiving').

verses.text: For your mercy toward me is great, and you have delivered my soul from the depths of Sheol.
verses.comment: Deliverance from Sheol hints at the resurrection hope and Christ's descent to the dead (1 Pet. 3:19), central in the ancient Church's creed.

verses.text: O God, arrogant men have risen up against me, and a band of violent men seeks my life; they do not set you before them.
verses.comment: Opposition by the proud and violent reflects the persecution experienced by the faithful, and ultimately Christ. It foreshadows martyrdom and strengthens calls to unity in the face of adversity.

verses.text: But you, O Lord, are a God compassionate and gracious, slow to anger and abundant in mercy and truth.
verses.comment: The description of God here is foundational to all biblical revelation, found also in Exodus and repeated in Catholic liturgy (e.g., Kyrie Eleison).

verses.text: Turn to me and be gracious to me; grant your strength to your servant and save the son of your maidservant.
verses.comment: The motif 'son of your maidservant' connects to ancient promises and Marian themes, hinting at the special dignity of being devoted to God's service.

verses.text: Show me a sign of your favor, so that those who hate me may see and be put to shame, because you, O LORD, have helped me and comforted me.
verses.comment: Asking for a sign is not mere doubt but a desire for God’s visible action. Such signs find fulfillment in Christ’s miracles, with sacramental realities—visible signs of invisible grace—at the center of Catholic faith.
